head.supplied: Circular Head ¶ 8 May 1875 ¶ Dear Baron ¶ ¶ On Sunday last, I returned from my expedition, after an absence of 14 days — ¶ ¶ I was advised to proceed to Mount Ramsay ¶ first, as it is the highest p...

div.p: RB MSS M141, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

To proof.
MS found with a specimen of Richea sp. (MEL 2186074). Circular Head
Tas.
On Sunday last, I returned from my expedition, after an absence of 14 days —

I was advised to proceed to Mount Ramsay
All places named are in the north-eastern part of the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park, Tasmania. first, as it is the highest point of the three Mountains — I got to the top of the former, at 3 oclock on the afternoon of the 27., but with the exception of thousands of specimens of Richea P.
Probably an abbreviation for the species R. pandanifolia or R.
procera ; the same terminology is used in S. Emmett to M, 9 Novcember 1875 (in this edition as 79-11-00b).
very straight and tall, their habitat being confined to the last 500 feet — I saw nothing fresh — I send you a few specimens obtained thereat; Mount Ramsay I consider to be over 4000 feet and from its summit I had an extensive and glorious sight of the Eldon Range & many scores of other Mountains, snow began to fall, and continued to do so for some days covering all the country deeply with snow — the season was too late by two months, everything seemed destitute of seeds. On the 29 I ascended Mount Bischoff 19 miles further North, and found nothing but burnt bauera & naked blackened rock with 7 inches of snow on the SW side, which is covered by dense horyzontal
horizontal? scrub — so thick as to exclude the daylight its height is said to be 3014 feet St. Valentines Peak 3½ miles from Chiltern Surrey Hills had been frequently burnt and nothing was to be seen but dead bauera — Knoll Plains at the foot of Mount Ramsay about 3000 feet elevation would appear to be the best field for botany, but all flowers and seeds had dropped off — my walk extended over 235 miles, which I accomplished in 11 days — I intend to go again in the summer, say December when I hope to have more success — If you could also come over in the Argyle, I would accompany you to Mount Ramsay free of cash — it is the only place where anything fresh could be procured being a a
a repeated.
virgin forest free from fires — It is contemplated to open a track from thence to the Pieman river S.W. coast and I have tendered my services to the Government to open one [direct] from this, so as to strike the centre of the Granite country which is considered to occupy the whole space — I should thus have an opportunity of getting upon fresh ground. — It is 105 miles from this to the summit of Mount Ramsay.

I send by the Argyle the few specimens that I was enabled to procure — Mr Harman informed me that he saw another tree similar to the one cut down about 1 to 1½ miles further on, where you and I went
In January and February 1875, during M's visit to Stanley, Tas and surrounding area; see M to R. Ramsay, 27 January 1875, and M to R. Ramsay, 6 February 1875.

div.p: Specimens forwarded to agents of the Argyle Melbourne.
